posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
I’m happy to (finally) announce the 2025 release of the FRC Web Components dashboard!

image 1530×715 117 KB

image 1530×715 117 KB

image 1530×715 117 KB

FRC Web Components (FWC) is a project started in 2020 that provides tools to help teams create custom web based dashboards. A couple years ago I created a Shuffleboard like application built using the FWC component library . Since then some great new dashboard alternatives such as Elastic have been released which fill the needs of most teams. However, if you’re interested in creating custom dashboards and enjoy using web technologies I encourage you to try this project out!

The app can be installed from here: Release FWC Dashboard 2025.1.3 · frc-web-components/app · GitHub

A web hosted version of the dashboard is also available if you’d like to try it.  You can even connect to your simulated robot right from your browser: FWC Dashboard

Dashboard documentation can be found here: frc-web-components/docs/dashboard.md at master · frc-web-components/frc-web-components

Plugin documentation can be found here: frc-web-components/docs/plugins.md at master · frc-web-components/frc-web-components

This year the dashboard app has been completely refactored and now uses React for rendering and Redux for state management. The project previously relied on a lot of custom stuff as well as some lesser known libraries such as Lit . I found this to be a turn off for would-be developers looking to contribute. I decided to switch to a software stack that was more familiar and approachable. This was a lot of work and contributed to the late release, but I’m hoping long term the switch will make it easier for myself and others to continue supporting the project. There’s still work left to be done on documentation and probably a few bugs that will need to fixed, but I wanted to make a post about this before it becomes too late in the season.

Aside from refactors, other significant updates have been made this year, particularly to the user interface:

A new layout manager was added powered by React FlexLayout . Tabs can now be rearranged into rows, columns, and tab groups:

This is a frequently requested feature from other dashboards such as Elastic and Shuffleboard:

Components can now be arranged in a grid:

Components can be changed to other components that accept the same type of source that it’s current assigned. This can be done by right clicking a selected component and selecting from the Show As… menu:

image 1197×500 38.8 KB

image 1197×500 38.8 KB

image 1197×500 38.8 KB

A lot of the improvements here were pulled from AdvantageScope so a huge thank you to AdvantageScope and its team of developers!

NT4 client has been upgraded to 4.1

Added support for structs

The dashboard subscribes to all topics only while editing. While competing only the topics used by your components will be subscribed to.

The dashboard now includes built-in layouts which can be opened from the File > Open Example… menu. Currently only a YAGSL Swerve layout is available, but more will be added soon:

Component behavior can be modified through their properties. Properties can be edited from the “Properties” panel:

Properties can be externally controlled by binding them to sources. In previous versions you could only bind a source directly to the component. In the 2025 release you can now also bind sources directly to individual properties:

In the image above the NetworkTables “/box” source has 2 children: /box/value and /box/Label . The children are mapped to properties in the component (the keys are converted to camel case, so an exact match is not required). Another source is bound directly to the “trueColor” property.

The plugin API is now simpler and more consistent between different front-end frameworks. Plugins can be created using React, Svelte, Lit, and any front-end framework that supports web components.

Here’s an example of a simple component created using the plugin API with React and Svelte:

The component will be typed based on the properties you provide the component:

image 1207×342 21.7 KB

image 1207×342 21.7 KB

image 1207×342 21.7 KB

Plugins can be built and imported into your dashboard. Once imported plugin components will be available to add:

(Using an image here because the text is preventing me from creating the topic for some reason)

image 625×640 25.1 KB

image 625×640 25.1 KB

image 625×640 25.1 KB

If you have any questions, suggestions or find any bugs feel free to post here or create an issue in the github repo: Issues · frc-web-components/frc-web-components

posts.cooked:
I lovee FWC. I hope my students will try to make their own webpage in it to have a “custom” dashboard.

Thank you for your work on it!

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
I’ve been longing for something like this for a while.

What I would REALLY love is the ability to deploy it to a robot out of the box and hosting an HTTP server on the RIO to access the dashboard.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
bathtubed:

ability to deploy it to a robot out of the box and hosting an HTTP server on the RIO to access the dashboard.

Put it in the deploy directory, start a webserver , and Bob’s your uncle!

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
I might give it a try! (though we’re a cpp team).

My hesitation was that there might be non trivial server side code running here in the desktop version.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/cpp/classwpi_1_1_web_server.html

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: Ah I was looking it up on my phone and goofily searched “Http” and “Server” (coming up with nothing) forgetting that it starts with “Web.”

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
This is a great idea! It is technically possible to do this by hosting a web server as @Peter_Johnson mentioned. Here’s an example of this working:

image 1663×432 40.4 KB

image 1663×432 40.4 KB

image 1663×432 40.4 KB

And here it is running in sim:

image 1356×572 31.2 KB

image 1356×572 31.2 KB

image 1356×572 31.2 KB

The biggest issue here is that the dashboard app’s static assets are quite large (9MB total) which could be an issue with the limited network bandwidth you get at competitions. These assets are static so they would only need to be downloaded when the robot first connects, and as long as your browser can cache the files this should only happen once. I think for this to work you’d need a stripped-down version of the dashboard for display purposes only (no editing capabilities) to reduce its size and the ability to export a layout from the app as a file that can be dropped into the deploy folder and served directly from there.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
Sweet! Yeah I will definitely experiment with this with some simulated bandwidth limiting over wifi.

So what would I need to add to the “dashboard” directory, is that the same as the “dashboard” directory in the source, or do I need packages to install via a full npm installation locally first?

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked:
AmoryG:

I found this to be a turn off for would-be developers looking to contribute

This is a pity as Lit uses open web standards.

Still slick work.

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
Created a new release with support for this: Release FWC Dashboard 2025.2.0 · frc-web-components/app

You can save the layout as an html file using the “Export for Web…” feature from the file menu:

image 872×592 51.2 KB

image 872×592 51.2 KB

image 872×592 51.2 KB

The file should be saved inside the folder containing the fwc build within the deploy directory:

image 1127×673 31 KB

image 1127×673 31 KB

image 1127×673 31 KB

I created an example robot project you can use to experiment with: frc-web-components/robot-project-examples/WebServer at master · frc-web-components/frc-web-components

Save the html file to the src/main/deploy/dashboard folder:

Run in sim and you should be good to go:

image 1756×876 113 KB

image 1756×876 113 KB

image 1756×876 113 KB

Note: This is still experimental and the build hasn’t been optimized for hosting from the roborio. It’s still a 9MB monster and has most of the editing capabilities of the dashboard app. Also this feature doesn’t currently support plugins. Still working on that but I thought this at least will help you get started.

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked: I was definitely conflicted about moving away from lit. I’m a big fan of web components and relying on web standards vs. libraries like react. I was hoping Lit would catch on more since I first started the project back in 2020, but adoption has been pretty slow. That said, even though the dashboard app is now built with react you can still build components and plugins using lit, svelte and any other framework that supports web components (at least theoretically since there’s many I haven’t tried).

posts.name: Gavin Kistner
posts.cooked:
Thank you for this. My team (and I) would very much like to use this. I’m sad to report that the .dmg does not work for macOS, and I’m embarrassed to admit that I can’t figure out the first step for how to see/use anything from the repo.

For the app, anything I can do to help debug the issue?

For the repo, is there a step I’m missing? Is pnpm dev supposed to launch a GUI?

link_counts.title: v1.2 .dmg does not work on macOS · Issue #20 · frc-web-components/app · GitHub
Cannot figure out how to launch the dashboard · Issue #192 · frc-web-components/frc-web-components · GitHub

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
Hi @Phrogz , I’m sorry for the trouble, I admit I have not done a lot of testing on macOS and I appreciate your efforts to debug the issue. Are you by chance seeing an error that looks like this?

There’s a process for signing and notarizing a macOS app that I haven’t gone through, so if you’re seeing this issue then it’s likely its being blocked. I had to get around this issue with the following command:

Are you running a mac with one of the newer apple silicon chips, or one of the older intel ones? I’ve only tested with my M2 macbook pro so there might be issues I’m not aware of on different models.

As far as developing in that repo you were on the right track, but unfortunately the documentation is very confusing and out of date. I’ll spend some time updating the docs and address the concerns you posted in the issue and this thread here.

To run the app you’ll have to first run pnpm dev as you’ve already done. This builds the other packages the dashboard relies on and watches for changes. Once that is done in a separate terminal you’ll have to run pnpm dashboard:dev which launches the dashboard in the browser using vite.

However, what you probably want is run in the tauri app: frc-web-components/app: Tauri app for FRC Web Components dashboard

This requires rust as well as npm. Once cloned you’ll have to run npm install and then npm run tauri:dev to launch the app. I’ll also add developer documentation to this repo as well.

posts.name: Antônio Miranda De Assis
posts.cooked: Hello, how are you, Amory? I was looking through all your documentation about FRC WEB Components, because I’m working on a robot project that needs a front-end with a dynamic and complete interface. I’m using Studica Robotics Hardware, which in general all the programming is the same as FRC , but it only supports VScode and WPILIB version 2020. My current problem is that I can’t pull the encoder values ​​to run on my front-end. Do you have an example just to pull the value?

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked: Hello @toninhowow , are you interested in using the app, or building a custom dashboard using the component library? The dashboard app uses a newer version of NetworkTables (4.1) and is incompatible with older versions of WPILib which uses NetworkTables version 3. The dashboard can communicate directly with an NT4 server since it uses websockets, while back in the NT3 days additional tools like pynetworktables2js needed to be used as well. If you’d like I can assist with creating a plugin that allows the dashboard to communicate with an NT3 server using pynetworktables2js. Alternatively, I can help get you started with a React, Svelte or some other web based template that uses the component library and pynetworktables2js?

link_counts.title: GitHub - robotpy/pynetworktables2js: Forwards NetworkTables traffic to a web page, allowing you to write custom dashboards for your robot using HTML/Javascript

posts.name: Antônio Miranda De Assis
posts.cooked:
I am interested in creating a custom dashboard! So far, I have completed the full programming of the Robot using the 2020 version of WPILib. In my WEB interface, I set up the Operator’s camera by creating a simple action stream using USB port 1181 along with the robot’s IP address. I also added a JS function to capture the image and achieve my goal of displaying the date and the encoder value—which, in the robot’s programming, is already calculated in millimeters. However, I am really lost on how to retrieve the encoder value. I looked into pynetworktables2js, ran it in my WEB project, and also implemented the FRCWebComponents script that you shared!  Can you tell me what the next step is?

imagem_2025-03-20T18-47-57-686Z 1920×1080 226 KB

imagem_2025-03-20T18-47-57-686Z 1920×1080 226 KB

imagem_2025-03-20T18-47-57-686Z 1920×1080 226 KB

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
Hello, apologies for the very late reply, been a bit overwhelmed helping my team prepare for week 5 and dcmp competitions. I created an example you can use to help you get started: amorygalili/pynetworktables2js-dashboard

It includes instructions on how to install/run pynetworktables2js and the dashboard. I have only tested it with the latest version of wpilib, so let me know if it works with your version. I’ll work on expanding the docs and adding more examples on how to use components. Let me know how it goes and if you run into any issues! I put it together pretty quickly so there might be some bugs.

posts.name: Antônio Miranda De Assis
posts.cooked: Thank you very much! I was able to get the result I was looking for! I was very interested in this FRC WB and will definitely pass this great project on to my team.
